It looks like the inside of a casino. Wall-to-wall carpet, glass chandeliers, wood paneling. The tables are packed in, and the place was full to the gills on Friday night. It was fairly raucous. The ambiance is not unpleasant; it's just very lively. Perfect for people watching. \n\nThey seat you and bring bread, good coleslaw and pickles right away, which is nice. We ordered the shrimp cocktail, a ribeye and a porterhouse, fries, a Montecarlo potato and mushrooms. The sides were tasty. The steaks were not. This place is a classic ""don't be fooled by the outside"" place. Located across from CPCC in an unassuming strip mall with a tiny parking lot, this little gem is just waiting to make your date more interesting, your mouth do a little dance and your wallet skip a beat!

I always go for lunch here because it's $5.99-$6.99 for the same size portions as dinner (dinner is around $10-$12). I always get the spicy chicken dish and await the fun. 

To those who don't know (I didn't before I went here!), Ethiopian food doesn't come with utensils, instead it's plated on this spongy bread which you break off and use to pick up the food. It's amazing and like I mentioned above, a great place to take a date.

Is it happening again? Seems the ownership is changed, I don't recognize the people that used to be here. The food is not the same and not in a good way, I just had the lunch special with the $2 upcharge for shrimp instead of chicken. The shrimp is undercooked, lower grade and on 4 little ones for the extra $2. I guess it breaks down to 50 cent per shirmp that isn't even close to as good as it was. The Pad Thai Noodles are all clumped together and you can't use the cheap flimsy plastic fork to even get through it. The noodles are dark brown and full of what taste like GARLIC! I just ordered it and picked it up, how does it taste like yesterday's leftovers? Who is back there now in the kitchen? it can't be the same cook, just awful.\nI don't know what is going on here, it's like the same old game again Good food and well prepared

I ordered the duck curry. It was listed on a sign outside as a ""special"" dish. It looked nice and red and yummy on the sign. When I got my duck curry, the look alone had me concerned. It was a light custardy color. The taste... bland as hell. I've never had such a bland curry before. Yeah, the waitress forgot to ask me what spice level I wanted, but this was just ridiculous. 

The other ingredients weren't bad, although they added little cherry tomatoes to try and boost the flavorless curry. The duck was ok, and the veggies were fresh. This fact didn't help me enjoy my curry though, unfortunately.

My new favourite hotel in Montreal.

Rooms are massive; you get a living room, a kitchen (full fridge, stove, dishwasher, and microwave), a giant bathroom, and a bedroom. Kitchen has no cutlery/plates/etc but you can request them by calling downstairs. If you're lucky your suite will have a giant jacuzzi (i'm 6'2"" and i fit in like a glove).

I was here as part of a group so internet was included for free (pro-tip: it's always free in the lobby). As someone who travels a lot the internet was good: it was stable and had adequate signal throughout the suite. Anyone who expects speedy/cheap internet in a hotel is naive (or hasn't done much travelling). I got strong LTE signal (Rogers) on my phone, so could have tethered too.

The bodyshop (whom I had a working relationship with as I am a former auto dealer) outsourced finding a replacement to Wheel Specialists. Wheel Specialists sent the body shop a replica M Parallel. The rim was obviously a replica as the lip was slightly different, the color was slightly different, and the rim lacked the OEM BMW markings. Getting an OEM rim was very important as the OEM rims were forged and the replica was not. I told the bodyshop I would handle the mix up. I went to wheel specialists directly to handle the situation and I dealt with Brad. He was a gigantic asshole. He refused to admit the rim was a replica. He basically told me I didn't know what I was talking about (even though I specialized for years in BMW's). Craving some chips, salsa, and a burrito, a small group of us sauntered into Pasqual's earlier this week. We were immediately seated (in the bar area), and placed an order for some brews.

Two of the brews were unavailable - they had sold out. Substitutions were made and chips with queso were ordered.

I'm familiar with many styles of queso... but I was shocked by Pasqual's ""queso"" - it was more like a soft-spread, cream-cheese-infused queso-wannabe. Rather than a soft, flowing, warm queso, this was cold and hard-packed in a small Solo cup. Definitely unusual, and largely tasteless. Two salsas accompanied the ""queso"" - neither were exceptional.

Dinner orders were placed: taco plate, a chicken fajita burrito, and a veggie burger (don't ask).

The food arrived fairly quickly, and portions were impressive if nothing else. My burrito was stuffed full of black beans, grilled chicken, and a few veggies. A massive serving of black beans (not refried - yay!) filled-out the rest of the plate. The burrito was decent, but again - bland and not remarkable by any means.

We were in town for one Saturday night and walked around the area hoping to find a place for dinner. We stepped in Bonaparte and felt embarrassed by being underdressed. However they still accommodated us for a table for 2 in this busy evening. 

When we were looking at the menu prices, we thought it was all about the nice decor. Once we started our meal, we immediately realized knew that the quality & presentation worth such prices.

I had soup of the day (red vegetable soup) and a lobster salad. The soup was great, though I would appreciate a tiny tad more of flavor enhancement (maybe some herb?). The lobster salad with hazelnut oil and maple syrup was delicious! Every element on the plate tasted so fresh and harmonious with each other. Nothing is overpowering another. The oil and syrup were lightly but thoroughly applied, leaving no greasy texture but beautiful scent in your mouth. The lobster meat was also nicely poached with nice fresh texture.

My husband ordered the 3 courses meal with brushetta, milk-fed calf steak, and chocolate mousse. The brushetta was nicely plated.

The library kicksass and here is why.\nSo you want to read a book, well go to http://library.scottsdaleaz.gov/ and see if they have it. If so, well go get it, if its checked out you can request a hold on it and when its returned they send you an email telling you its in and hold it for you up to 10 days. \nAs well as books they have DVDs and VHS movies. You can check out up to 10 at a time for 3 weeks. The selection is pretty good also. Now they have current releases but those are usually always checked out or reserved. So don't go expecting to get the most recent Will Smith or Seth Rogan movie. What you can get are alot of the movies that are on AFI's top 100 movie list. They have a good amount of Criterion Collection movies.

An impressively good pub considering its recent opening.

PRICE: Reasonable.

SIZE: Has a large feel to it but is in fact not too big, with plenty of seating about, and a couple of extra seats in the alcove towards the front. 

FEEL: The pub has an open feel to it, and is decorated in a tasteful, traditional manner.

RANGE: The pub stocks a regularly replenished supply of real ale, and they also have a wide selection of whiskies and spirits. No Strongbow to be seen (a good thing), and instead they have real cider on tap.

TOILETS: Can be accessed from two sides if the bar is busy. They are clean, decorated like the rest of the pub and with modern, functional fittings.

Now here is a good pub.

These guys are doing something interesting, and I like it. Gourmet hotdogs with Korean style toppings. I thought my lunch here was great, and my only wish is that they were closer to my job!

I ordered the Angry Hotdog ($4.95), and the Angry Kimchi fries ($4.95). The fries were actually sweet potato fries, covered in kimchi, an egg over easy, bulgogi, and Korean spices. It had a small little bite to it that I actually would have preferred stronger. The fries didn't come together so good for me. I'm just not sure if the sweetness of the sweet potato goes with the spicy, meaty flavors of the bulgogi and Korean chili sauce. They were good, but not great, and a little bit too greasy for me.

I took my mom, sister, and niece to the Slider Truck at the Farmers' Market on Eastern and Richmar (Serene-ish).

I have two favorites... one being the Pulled Porky (listed as a specialty slider - limited time?) with jalapenos. Spicy and sweet - one of my all time favorite combinations - with a nice hit (slightly more than a hint?) of spice that gives a nice depth to the flavors.  They clearly market and cater to the older local population, evidenced by crowds toting the most recent giveaway, which happened to be bathrobes. Yes, bathrobes. Now don't get me wrong, BJ and I have had a lot of fun with this group. In our bathrobes. (JK)

I thought that was great bc I was still learning to balance a checkbook and hardly ever had more than $200 in my account at a time. I filled out all the paper work and the teller said it would be applied right away as a back up.

Well, that didn't happen. I overdrafted several times thinking it would pull it from my card and ended up with almost $300 in overdraft fees.

she then explained to me that my paper work have been misplaced. this is when i freaked out.

Las Vegas is known for The Strip, several miles of massive resort casinos that will do just about anything to catch a visitor's attention. City Center complex is no exception.

This ultra modern, sleek design mixed use area is home to the Mandarin Oriental hotel. Upon entering the MO, guests travel up to the twenty-third floor to the Sky Lobby a refreshingly unique concept. However the Tea Lounge is just sort of there by the check-in desk. It has all the charm of a Starbucks kiosk in any lobby in any hotel in any major city in the country.

Once seated guests are treated to an amazing view of the city. The couches are extremely comfortable for lounging, not necessarily ideal for eating. The tea selections are seemingly endless with different herbal/floral combinations. The food offerings are meager to put it nicely. This is after all a high tea experience not a true meal. Conveniently placed close to the airport, rental car service also close by with big rooms that are clean and come with basic needs.

I came in with my mother to the lobby where our room had already been reserved, showed proof and was given our two room keys and directions to our room. We took our car around back and was able to park right in front of our hotel room. 

The basic room was spacious, with two Queen sized beds, bathroom/shower, TV, refrigerator, of course AC and wi-fi. We loved our room, it had every thing we needed except for a good coffee maker and microwave. The coffee maker was more of a water boiler and the microwave was available in a small cabinet in the lobby, which looked to be dated from the 80s. Came here with my boyfriend last weekend for a living social deal we got, which was a total steal! It was $199 for Friday 3pm -Sunday 1pm in a suite with a King SIze bed (plus 100 bucks towards the spa, 2 free breakfast buffets, and 6 free bowling games). Didn't really know what to expect because we've never stayed anywhere in Vegas except for the strip.\n\nOverall, we were pleasantly surprised that this place was pretty nice! The hotel itself is pretty modern and luxurious for the price we paid. The room was awesome. Great size, great view! The bed was super comfy, and the restroom was really nice and clean! The buffets were way cheaper than any other hotel I've ever gone to. The casino was okay and decently sized. Not as busy as casinos on the strip. Yeah, you may be far from the strip but there's a shuttle that takes you there for free (:! It was nice seeing Vegas for once without the hustle and bustle!

Seriously if you have not been here yet - get in your car and get over there. I went because it got good reviews, it was new to me and it was Mexican food which was what I wanted today. Big surprise - fantastic food.

The restaurant is not in a swanky neighborhood but don't let that stop you. They are in a shopping center that has several other restaurants, some closed, and a sports bar. Look for it because it is not obvious.

From the pictures on yelp you might think they do not have many tables BUT they have a room next door with plenty of seating.

The motif is Mexican wrestling thus the Lucha Libre name. Pretty well done and fun if you have not been around that before.

OK OK, the food! When they ask you to try a taste of what they offer DO IT! every taste is different and every one is fantastic. The one they will tell you is the hottest meat will in fact remove all of your throat so be careful. All of the other ones

This is probably one of the most disappointing meals we've had from a chef of this high caliber.

Perhaps because the restaurant is newly opened and the menu hasn't been perfected (well, that is still no excuse for overcooking beef)?

Unlike the other low rating reviewer - service was really good for us. ambiance and table seating and arrangement was also not an issue. The only problem we had was entirely on the food.

I like the different tasting dishes but some times it felt really disjointed and confused, as if it lacked something to tie all the small dishes together. 

The langoustine tasting was quite fun and interesting. While some of the dishes were amazing, others were like, huh? And the sake shot? I was like..hum...not sure why they are doing a shot of sake when they just sold us a bottle of really expensive wine...didn't really enhance the langoustine or the overall tasting experience. 

My husband's steak was overdone. He ordered rare, and the beef came out barely pink. We didn't want to send it back and just decided to concentrate on my venison which was prob one of the best I have ever had. 

The dessert tasting was fun and

This place is 3 stores in one, a restaurant, a bakery and a meat market. I would give the restaurant 2.5 stars, the bakery 4 stars and meat market 5+stars.

I've only eaten at the restaurant once; my Mom and her husband love this place - so on her recommendation a couple friends and I went for a prime rib dinner. My friends and I are not young, but we were the youngest people there. No problem, it was 8pm and we were starving. We each ordered the prime rib dinner which came with soup, potato and a dessert. The soup was some sort of cream soup that was so gelatinous the spoon stood straight up in the sticky glop, yuck! Thank God the prime rib was brought out quickly, it was FANTASTIC! Medium rare, tender, tasty in it's own juice. Delicious! It's a good thing we weren't hungry for dessert, it was some sort of pudding that had the same gelatinous appearance as the soup earlier. Gross.

I've only stopped through the bakery once for some cookies. Everything is made fresh daily and they'll take special requests for anything including sugar free and low fat items. 

Go here

This is close to my house when I need to pick up something in a pinch. like jasmine rice, soy sauce or rice vinegar.
Being Thai, I find that they lack alot of Thai ingredients. Mostly pre packaged curries and bottled sauces and thats it. However, they do have lots of Korean and Indian items.
The produce section is nice. But no kaffir lime leaves or galangal. Lemon grass shows up every now and then. They do have nice fresh veggies(herbs) like: garlic, chinese chives,beansprouts,thai basil.
I have been to the bakery, and I wouldnt reccomend it. The food looks like it's been sitting out awhile and does not look fresh. I do like their skincare isle, you can find Shisheido products here for less straight from Japan. The home goods isle is always fun to browse through. My daughter likes to pick out different types of chopsticks. And they have steamers and rice

This place is a real gem for those who like to geek out or are true history buffs (that would include my son and husband). We took a visit to Vegas with the family and really wanted to check this place out. We got in here with a Groupon which was $48 for the whole family (5 people) plus access to Area 51.
There are two areas in this exhibit - Area 51 and the National Atomic Testing Museum (NATM).
Area 51 is all about extraterrestrial life and aliens. There are cheesy electronic sounds, alien dolls and some news articles on sightings. They have old radio broadcasts and some video clips. I definitely would not pay full price for access to this area, but if you get in on a Groupon deal, definitely take it. My kids, who are 14, 11, 9 were intrigued.
The NATM is really well done. Lots of information, pictures, videos and facts. They keep the exhibits interesting and interactive. Lots of tactile demonstrations for kids to play with too. They have a video room which demonstrates what a real nuclear bomb would have felt like if you were nearby and gives a brief bio on the testing performed by those who worked during those times. The Lost Dog Wash Trail and I (as well as Bry and our two labradors) had the pleasure of meeting each other at the end of April. Even at a little after 8am, there was a freak storm hovering nearby so we had some concerns with ""surviving"" the trail and getting back in time before getting fully rained on. To our relief, the hike was easy as pie and had little elevation gain, but we did encounter one small problem. We were talking and missed a turn and ended up adding another trail and a half or so to our loop as well. We followed along the Lost Dog Wash Trail and then ended up on the Ringtail Trail and then to the Old Jeep Trail. So with our little mishap, instead of taking a short little sub 3 mile hike for one of our elderly pups, we ended up on the 4.1 mile one. Oh well, we took it nice and slow for our older labrador. We did get rained on a bit close to the end, but like I said, it seldom rains, so it's rarely a problem.

-Awesome views

The lazy mechanic took it of and never put it back . And i just changed my air filter and they tell me it needs to be replaced WTF . They say they put A synthetic blend oil Yeah right .
DO NOT TAKE YOUR CAR THERE !!!!
 I should have known I will never again take my car to this losers !!! If you want a good place to take your car in Henderson go to SUNSET AUTO they are real Professionals there .
that's what I get for trying to save money on a oil change . 
 So I call the the Corporate office and they tell me that they would send me something but since i to anxious to hate what ever that means that they don't care and they tell me

I ate here last week. I initially enjoyed the ambiance, the nice wait staff, and the wide selection of sushi, robata, and cocktails. However, our food and drinks were littered with inedible garnishes. One of our drinks contained inedible wood sticks and leaves, while the plate came with a side of hollowed out crustacean appendages.

While I understand that the harvested tree parts add to the flavor of the drink, the crustacean carcases added nothing to the plate other than to disgust their customers. It was sickening. I almost sent the food back, but I decided to give it a try.

Fortunately the food and drinks were decent. They weren't memorable in the sense that I will tell my friends and family about it, but the food and drinks were a good attempt at sushi, robata, and cocktails. I would give the quality of the food 3 stars.

However, when I spoke with the manager about the disproportionate amount of inedible food on the

I had mentioned to my boyfriend that I needed to renew my eyeglass prescription, and he mentioned the deal America's best had where you can get an eye exam and 2 pairs of glasses including the lenses for $69.99. I needed contacts as well and when I called the store, I specifically asked if there was a way to get both the eyeglass and contact lens exam for an additional cost. The woman on the phone told me for $79.99 I could have both the eyeglass exam and contact lens exam, so just $10 more. \n\nI made an appointment and saw the doctor as usual, discussed my options for both glasses and contacts and then proceeded to pick out 2 frames to go along with the deal I had called about. UGH! Turns out after sitting down to finalize everything that the contact lens exam was BY ITSELF $79.99 and there were no glasses or anything included! The staff apologized for the miscommunication, but at that point I had both called to get the correct information and ended up spending a good hour and a half in the store picking

We dined here this evening with my daugher's dance studio being located in the same plaza. We were both super excited to get a Greek place nearby and had waited anxiously since we saw the signage up prior to opening. It was pretty disappointing, I am sad to say :(\n\nWe had to wait about 5 minutes at the counter to place our order and finally, I think one of the owners, came over to assist us in our order. We waited almost 40 minutes for one gyro plate and one souvlaki plate although they did bring out soup samples to all the tables which was very thoughtful. The gyro was nothing to write home about, the meat on the top of the pita was very very crispy, crunchy in fact which oddly enough, added a pleasant texture. The sauce was standard and was just the right amount. The rice was a STANDOUT....super fluffy but in need of a little more seasoning. My husband's souvlaki pita was tasty, the meat was lean, moist

I was in Las Vegas a couple of weeks ago for work. On Friday night we went out for a group dinner at Enoteca. I have never been to this establishment but having been to Carnevino and having a WONDERFUL dinner I had expectations. 

Enoteca is a bit more casual and low key than Carne and offers pastas, pizzas and a small variety of entrees. 

Our group started with a selection of cheeses, Prosciutto di Parma and fried squash blossoms. Not being a cheese fan I passed on the cheese and sampled the prosciutto and blossoms. YUM! The Prosciutto was delicate, just a bit salty and a nice light beginning to the meal. The squash blossoms were filled with some sort of cheese mixture, lightly battered and deep fried. And though fried they were still very light and airy. DELISH! I've never had squash blossoms but this app made me a fan! 

For dinner I had the the Marinated Chicken Paillard. WOW! What

OWNERS - STAY AWAY FROM THEM!!!!!!!!
Read the other reviews. They are all true. This company could care less about you and your tenants. I will not even go into my long long list of problems because they have an excuse to justify everything that they do to people. Look at how much time the owner spends responding to complaints on this site. He does not know how to say ""I am sorry, I did not service your account correctly, let me fix it"". Instead he puts 100% of his effort into laying blame at everyone else's feet and getting onto these sites to justify his reasons for treating people badly. 

His office staff is horrible starting with his wife. They have set a horrible tone in their company and it carries through to every single person that works for them. They use their own in house maintenance department that does a horrible job as well. I have had to have so many things reworked that they did.

Shocker folks, I don't normally like hot dogs. The only way you can hand me a hot dog I'll actually eat is if it's fresh off the grill. With loads of ketchup...and I DO mean loads, like buckets full! If I ever think of eating a hot dog without ketchup, the world may end. The world kinda did tonight...a little.\n\nI ordered the New York Dog and the Sweetbread Dog, plus the duck fat fries to split with my friend. I had to order the NYC Dog because I love me some sauerkraut. I ordered the Sweetbread dog because it had the word \""sweet\"" in it. No lie. Please don't judge, but I thought sweetbread was like cornbread (I see you rolling your eyes foodies!). So I imagined this dog in between a roll that's actually corn bread...perhaps another creation Mr. Sousa? Anyway, I digress... The sweetbread I actually found out is...I suggest you look it up (but a hint: it deals with hearts and throats of animals). I'm willing to

If I could post zero stars, that's what I would do. Let me preface this with the fact that we got here at 7pm on a Saturday...busy time for sure, but a restaurant should be able to forecast for that. After placing our orders, our waiter let's me know that I got the last order of brisket available (again, it's only 7pm on a saturday). Next, our food comes and here's where the real fun starts. My Mom's pulled pork looks chopped (as opposed to actually pulled) and it's DRY AS A BONE. I live in Chicago and maybe I'm a bit of a BBQ snob, but meats should be able to stand on their own...they shouldn't require sauce to make it moist or give it taste. Best part? They didn't have enough containers for sauce to go around so we had to wait like 5 minutes before they even brought us any! Now, on to my entree. I ordered
sampled:
We had dinner here last night. It was our second time eating at Moishes, and the place had been remodeled since the last time we were there about a decade ago. It looks like the inside of a casino. Wall-to-wall carpet, glass chandeliers, wood paneling. The tables are packed in, and the place was full to the gills on Friday night. It was fairly raucous. The ambiance is not unpleasant; it's just very lively. Perfect for people watching.

They seat you and bring bread, good and warm with butter. We both ordered steaks, cooked to perfection, juicy and flavorful. Sides like creamed spinach were generous and delicious. Despite the bustling crowd, our service was attentive and efficient. Moishes truly delivers a classic steakhouse experience: lively, delicious, and memorable. It's not a quiet dinner spot, but perfect for an energetic night out with fantastic food.

Hmmmm - not sure how this place has won awards or was so busy the night we went. We were greeted promptly and seated right away, always a plus. We were greeted by two different waiters - not a big deal as they were busy. BUT when our waiter came up to the table (and it's really loud so it was hard to hear him) we weren't ready to order drinks yet, and after greeting us he just walked away. Again, it was loud so I'm not sure if he said anything but it didn't look like it. This abrupt departure set a negative tone. We waited another 15 minutes before anyone returned for our drink order, by which point we were ready for food too. The food itself was mediocre – lukewarm and bland, certainly not justifying the price. Service remained sparse and inattentive throughout. For a highly-rated, busy spot, the experience was a significant letdown. We won't be back.

Cox has super lousy customer service. From the phone reps to the techs to the supervisors. My appointment today (which was a bogus problem on their end, not mine) was for a 3 -5 pm window. So I worked to fit this time into my schedule and bargained with coworkers to get out of work early. 5:45 comes and nobody shows...So I call Cox. It is now 6:45 and I am still waiting for somebody to take me off hold. Meanwhile I am "live-chatting" with a rep named Maritza, who informs me there's no record of my technician being dispatched. No apology, just a shrug emoji in text form, essentially. This is beyond frustrating. My entire afternoon was wasted for their incompetence and utter disregard for customer schedules. If you have any other internet provider options, please, for your own sanity, choose them over Cox. This level of disrespect for a customer's time is absolutely unacceptable. Save yourself the headache and the endless hold music.

This was probably one of the most disappointing massages I've had in my life. The location doesn't look like much from the outside, but the inside is pretty nice. The massage tables are heated and really comfortable – perhaps the only truly positive takeaway from our visit.

My friend and I made reservations for 50-minute massages, but decided when we got there that we wanted an 80-minute one. The receptionist said that they couldn't accommodate us, which is understandable at face value. However, when we were done, there was no one waiting to go next and it seemed like more than two masseuses were simply chatting in the hallway, indicating ample availability. This made the earlier refusal feel less about scheduling constraints and more about a lack of willingness to be flexible, which was quite frustrating. To top it off, the actual massage itself was mediocre at best, lacking the pressure and focus I needed. Given the unaccommodating service and the underwhelming session, I left feeling more frustrated than relaxed. Definitely won't be returning.

Definitely a theater that's showing its age. The last movie I saw here was the first Matrix movie... and I don't think much has been updated in the past 13+ years since then. Swung by to see Rush (by Ron Howard); it was a Sunday at 6:20pm - the parking lot was nearly empty. The ticket sales person was friendly; she made a little small talk and said that she heard Rush was a great film - apparently she was going to try to watch it tomorrow. I appreciated the chat; all too often, ticket windows feel like transactional turnstiles. The lobby felt stuck in the 90s, complete with faded carpet and an aroma of stale popcorn. Inside the theater, the seats were functional but clearly worn, lacking modern comfort. The screen itself was fine, and the sound for *Rush* was adequate, though not particularly immersive. It served its purpose for a casual Sunday night movie. While not a premium experience, the low crowd density was a plus. If you're looking for an affordable, no-frills screening, this place still delivers, but don't expect any bells or whistles.

This is a must read This place Sucks!

If there were a zero rating it would be deserving. My Roommate and I were greeted at the door with an employee named Griffin. Introductions were in order we sat down and at this point I just wanted to take a look at the gym to see what was available. Griffin was not having it! He ignored my request and wanted to continue with my goals. Told him I just wanted to do cardio and to lose weight. I asked to see the gym before we discussed prices so I have a better idea of what I’d be paying for. He completely brushed me off again, insisting we talk numbers first. It felt like a high-pressure sales tactic, not a welcoming introduction to a fitness center. He seemed more interested in closing a deal than genuinely helping me explore my options. We eventually just walked out, utterly disgusted. What a waste of time. Avoid this place if you value your time and want to actually see what you're buying.

I had my son's birthday party at the waterpark in the hotel. I was incredibly disappointed with the entire experience, from the moment we tried to book until we left. They advertise this service, and even offer coupons, but their policies are just baffling. For starters, I believe it's good business practice to honor coupons, even slightly expired ones, especially when the goal is to attract and retain customers. Refusing a coupon felt incredibly petty and unwelcoming.

Then there's the contradictory food policy. We were told we *needed* to bring our own cake, which is perfectly fine. However, they then strictly banned any other outside food items, even small snacks for the kids. It makes no sense to mandate one type of outside food while prohibiting everything else. The number of ridiculous rules made the whole party feel more like a military operation than a fun celebration. This waterpark needs to re-evaluate its approach to customer service and party planning.

This place is a classic "don't be fooled by the outside" place. Located across from CPCC in an unassuming strip mall with a tiny parking lot, this little gem is just waiting to make your date more interesting, your mouth do a little dance and your wallet skip a beat!

I always go for lunch here because it's $5.99-$6.99 for the same size portions as dinner (dinner is around $10-$12). I always get the spicy chicken dish and await the fun.

To those who worry about the spice, don't! It's a delightful, flavorful heat that perfectly complements the chicken. The lunch deal is unbeatable for portion size and quality. It’s quick, delicious, and a true hidden gem for an authentic, value-packed meal. Seriously, your taste buds (and wallet) will thank you!

Is it happening again? Seems the ownership is changed, I don't recognize the people that used to be here anymore. The food is absolutely not the same and not in a good way. I just had the lunch special with the $2 upcharge for shrimp instead of chicken. Honestly, the shrimp was undercooked, tasted lower grade, and there were only 4 little ones for that extra $2. I guess it breaks down to 50 cents per shrimp that isn't even close to as good as what they used to serve. To make matters worse, the Pad Thai Noodles were all clumped together, and you simply can't use the cheap, flimsy plastic cutlery they provide to even attempt to separate them. It's truly disappointing to see a place I once genuinely enjoyed go downhill so fast. The quality has plummeted across the board, from the ingredients to the overall execution. I used to be a regular, but this experience makes me question if I'll ever return.

Weera is the epitome of badly Americanized Thai food, at least as far as their curry goes. I was hopeful after calling them up and asking them if their recipes were different from Royal Thai. Royal Thai also had pretty lame curry, so I was excited to give Weera a try. I ordered the duck curry. It was listed on a sign outside as a "special" dish. It looked nice and red and yummy on the sign. When I got my duck curry, the look alone had me concerned. It was a light custardy orange hue, a far cry from the rich red advertised. The texture was thin and watery, completely lacking the creamy body of a proper curry. Taste-wise, it was bland and strangely sweet, more like a dessert than a savory dish. The duck was acceptable, but it couldn't salvage the uninspired sauce. For a "special," this was a huge letdown. My quest for decent Thai curry continues, as Weera's attempt was a definite miss. Steer clear of their curries.

I lived on the west side of town forever, but I recently moved to the east side. This meant finding a new local mechanic. My check engine light popped on, and my AC started acting up, even causing the car to overheat. I found this place on Yelp with promising reviews and decided to try them.

I made an appointment and dropped my car off at 7 AM. Upon arrival, I had to approach someone to check in, which felt a bit less organized. Seven hours later, at 2 PM, having heard nothing, I called. They informed me they had diagnosed the issue – a faulty AC compressor – and were preparing a quote. The quote came quickly and was quite reasonable. My car was ready by late afternoon. The AC is now ice-old, and the check engine light is gone. While initial communication could be improved, their repair work was solid and fairly priced. I'd consider them again.

Staying at the Stratosphere was right up there with THE worst experience I have ever had at a hotel stay. I have traveled all over and stayed at many different hotels from 2 stars to 5 stars and this takes the cake on one of the worst.

Not only did I find a COCKROACH on the first day on the night stand next to where we sleep at night..!!!!!! Which alone is horrible and appalling, but the tub was completely disgusting with hair left from previous hotel guests and other particles. I can't express how important cleanliness is to me, and these glaring issues made it impossible to feel comfortable or relax for a single moment. It was utterly disgusting, frankly a health concern, and completely ruined our stay. Having to constantly worry about pests and sanitation is not what you pay for in a hotel, especially in Las Vegas. The lack of basic hygiene was truly appalling and frankly, inexcusable. Save yourself the discomfort and disappointment; there are countless better, cleaner options out there. Avoid the Stratosphere if you value a decent, pest-free environment.

On 2/22 we had a company retreat in Rio. We have reserved 16 rooms and checked in all at the same time, paid all by a company credit card. There were not only room charges but also other charges like ball room, meeting equipment, beverage, and so on. While believing we have paid for everything, today 6/6 I received this collection call from a collection agent. His name is Nelson. He said that it is reported to credit agency that $72.00 was unpaid. All the 16 rooms and all the expenses, thousands of dollars were paid, and **now we're dealing with a collection agency for a paltry $72! This is absolutely outrageous. Four months post-event, to have our company's credit potentially impacted over such a minor, likely erroneous charge, after spending thousands, is a testament to their utterly incompetent billing system. This administrative headache and reputational risk are completely unacceptable. What a way to ruin a good corporate retreat experience with such amateurish financial management. Businesses, consider this a warning!**

I got to the restaurant, looking forward to some great Thai food in the area. Lunch hours end at 2:30 (they close before dinner), and I arrived at 2:10. Didn't think it would be a big deal. When I walked in, the lady immediately told me that they close at 2:30 and handed me a menu as if I should order takeout. I asked, "Can I eat here?" and she said I could. I sat down, looked at the menu for maybe 1 minute, and she came by and wanted to take my order. I felt instantly rushed and unwelcome. It was clear she wanted me out, despite 20 minutes until closing. If they weren't ready for dine-in, they should have just said so, instead of making me feel like an inconvenience. I quickly ordered, ate faster than I ever have, and practically ran out. The food was forgettable, overshadowed by the terrible service. This place clearly prioritizes closing over customer service. Save your time; I won't be back.

First Impressions for me were: I'm here for an early middle of the week lunch and they have people in both rooms, it is not crowded at 11:30am yet there are several people already here. They let me sit where ever I want instead of just taking me to a table, nice though it does not effect my rating. I'm seated and I notice the "Garage Doors" Urban Architecture and simple Decor so I like this! It's got Potential! Plenty of Outdoor seating too, Great designs, this place is **definitely aiming for a modern, industrial-chic vibe that works beautifully. The high ceilings and natural light pouring in from those impressive garage doors create an open, airy atmosphere that feels both spacious and inviting. It's not overly fussy, just clean lines and thoughtful touches that make it feel fresh and relevant. The outdoor seating area looks particularly appealing for warmer days, promising a fantastic spot for people-watching or just enjoying the breeze. Everything about the aesthetic suggests a well-thought-out concept, and I can already envision this place buzzing with energy during peak hours. It clearly has the bones to be a local favorite.**

Have you ever gone to a steak house and lost weight? If you haven't, try BLT, as you'll not take home a doggie bag...ha. Is it also bad that the best part of the evening was the background music? I love me some Dobie Gray :)

Went to BLT for restaurant week today and was unfortunately not impressed. Coming from Chicago, I have a deep appreciation for a good steakhouse and have certainly spent my fair share of money at Charlotte's finest establishments. Sadly, BLT just doesn't measure up. The dishes were rather underwhelming, lacking the robust flavors and quality one expects from a top-tier steakhouse. For what they charge, even during restaurant week, the value just isn't there. It's truly disappointing to say, but BLT doesn't even crack my top 5 steakhouses in Charlotte. Skip the steak and just enjoy the tunes elsewhere.

Let me start by writing that the service was good, the waitress was prompt and attentive to the two of us. We were seated in a small room with 5 tables which was fine except that it was stuffy and a good look around the outdated room revealed a great deal of dust on rails etc. this of course makes you ask. What is the cleanliness in the kitchen? We had the tamales which was dry and the fois gras which was good. The squash was excellent and the spinach salad was excellent but way overdressed. We also had the lobster and basil pasta, which unfortunately was quite oily and the lobster was a bit tough, detracting from the overall dish. While the excellent service was appreciated, the hit-or-miss food quality combined with the noticeable lack of cleanliness in the dining area left us with significant reservations. It's hard to overlook such basic maintenance issues. For these reasons, we won't be rushing back.

My new favourite hotel in Montreal.

Rooms are massive; you get a living room, a kitchen (full fridge, stove, dishwasher, and microwave), a giant bathroom, and a bedroom. It's like having a full apartment! While the kitchen initially has no cutlery or plates, you can easily request them by calling downstairs, which is a convenient service. If you're lucky, your suite will even feature a giant jacuzzi – I'm 6'2" and I fit in like a glove, which was a luxurious touch after a long day.

I was here as part of a group so internet was included for free (pro-tip: it's typically an extra charge, so always inquire about package deals or loyalty programs if you're not part of a group). The location is fantastic, staff are friendly, and overall, it offers incredible value for the immense space and amenities provided. Highly recommend for extended stays or anyone who appreciates truly spacious accommodations!

So i see i got even more taken advantage of. BEWARE OF Finance guy *IMAD ALSAYEGH* Chubby Jordanian guy with an accent*****REALLY LOOK AT YOUR PAPERWORK BEFORE YOU SIGN***** i was told they will pay off my balance on my trade in and give me an amount of 13,600(in my previous review i explained how they made me pay another $80)13,600 was the payoff. This is how it was ACTUALLY paid off $13,000 was the trade in value that the dealership paid, $500 was my own money Imad added without my knowledge, making it seem like the dealership covered the full balance. This left $100 still unpaid on top of the $80 I already paid. Imad's promises were lies; he manipulates numbers to deceive. This dishonesty is infuriating. Do not trust him. Demand to see and verify every detail yourself before signing. Protect your money and learn from my terrible experience.

Back in 2007, my car (BMW 540i sport) was involved in a minor accident and one of the front rims was damaged (18" M Parallel). The bodyshop (whom I had a working relationship with as I am a former auto dealer) outsourced finding a replacement to Wheel Specialists. Wheel Specialists sent the body shop a replica M Parallel. The rim was obviously a replica as the lip was slightly different, the color was slightly different, and the rim lacked the OEM BMW markings. Getting an OEM rim was very important as the OEM rims perfectly matched the other three, ensuring consistent handling, aesthetics, and preserving the vehicle's value. The replica was an immediate red flag. My bodyshop relayed my insistence on an OEM part, but Wheel Specialists seemed intent on pushing the cheaper alternative. As a former auto dealer, I found their attempt to pass off a non-OEM part as suitable for a high-performance BMW utterly unprofessional and deceptive. This wasn't just a visual mismatch; it was about integrity. I ultimately sourced an OEM rim elsewhere. Based on this, I cannot recommend their services.

Craving some chips, salsa, and a burrito, a small group of us sauntered into Pasqual's earlier this week. We were immediately seated (in the bar area), and placed an order for some brews. Two of the brews were unavailable - they had sold out. Substitutions were made and chips with queso were ordered. I'm familiar with many styles of queso... but I was shocked by Pasqual's "queso" - it was more like a soft-spread, nearly liquid, and utterly devoid of the expected cheesy richness. It felt more like a warmed, bland dip from a jar than actual queso. A truly bizarre offering.

Our burritos, thankfully, were a different story. Generously sized and packed with flavorful fillings, they were a redeeming highlight. The chips were decent, and the salsa offered a pleasant, zesty kick. Service was a bit sluggish, possibly due to our bar seating, and the initial beer availability issue was a minor letdown. While the burritos prevented a complete culinary disappointment, that queso left a lasting, rather unappetizing impression. I might consider returning for a burrito, but the queso is a definite no-go.

I had a reservation for a compact car for 4 days. At the upstairs counter I declined to upgrade to a larger car for $5 per day. According to the Enterprise website, a compact car is a Nissan Versa, a Toyota Yaris, or similar. Anything similar to those two cars would have suited our needs perfectly. When we arrived at the cars in the parking garage, I was told we would be in a Fiat 500. While I am sure the Fiat would have been fun to drive, it was much too small for our needs. Looking at the technical specifications for the Fiat 500, it's clearly a subcompact, not a compact. Its cargo volume and passenger space are significantly less than a Versa or Yaris. We had luggage that simply wouldn't fit, completely derailing our travel plans. This felt like a major downgrade, especially after declining an upgrade. It caused significant stress and inconvenience. Not what I expect from a reputable rental company.

I'm training for my first full marathon in January, and with some longer training runs on the horizon I figured it was time for some new running shoes.

I came in on a Tuesday night, and walked into what was some sort of sponsored night for a high school cross country team so the place was plenty busy. I thought about going somewhere else or just coming back some other time, but instead I browsed some of the shoes I've been eyeballing online. I saw their foot analysis station, with a wait behind all those with the cross country people. When I was about to just leave, a staff member, Sarah, quickly approached me. Despite the chaos, she ensured I received personalized attention, guiding me efficiently through their excellent foot analysis. She then brought out several perfect options based on my running style and marathon needs. I left with a pair that felt custom-made and ready for the miles ahead. The dedication to customer service, even on such a busy night, was truly impressive. This place knows running shoes!

I have been here twice now. Once when they were brand new, and then again this past weekend.

THIS CLUB SUCKS! If you want an expensive, overly-hyped, WAY overcrowded club (they don't care about safety/fire hazards at XS - AT ALL!) that loves to drop the beat after every song, this is for you.

The first time, we had bottle service for my friend's birthday. He is usually pretty chill, but even with our table, the crowd was stifling. The DJ's constant beat-dropping every 30 seconds ruined any potential vibe; it was jarring and amateurish.

My second visit was just as bad. It's a beautiful venue, but management clearly prioritizes profit over a safe, enjoyable experience. Save your money and sanity; there are far better clubs in Vegas.

I have found my new favorite AYCE sushi joint in Vegas now. Before coming here, I was a fan of Yama Sushi, which is still really yummy, but now that I've been introduced to this place, I don't know...I think I might have to come here now rather than Yama. 

We arrived with a party of 6 and the hostess told us it would take about an hour and 15 minutes or so. The place is small with a main dining area and two larger tables to the side of the restaurant for larger parties. We decided to wait it out, and thankfully, we were seated a bit sooner, around the one-hour mark. Once inside, the energy was palpable. The service was prompt and friendly, even with the busy atmosphere. The sushi itself was incredibly fresh, the rolls were creative and generously sized, and the nigiri had the perfect rice-to-fish ratio. Everything tasted premium, a step above what I'm used to. The variety was excellent too. This spot truly impressed me, making the wait entirely worthwhile. I'm already planning my next visit!

Where do we start? The place is hot, dusty, very crowded, and so disorganized. Okay that aside, the reason why were giving this event a 1 star ( 0 if possible) is the false advertisement to various ticket sellers. They proudly say "trucks are asked to sell food on low price" this is well printed and customer service even answer this question on their website. Well let me save you the precious time, money and save you from getting angry. Not only you have to pay (12) dollars for entrance, you also have to pay parking (5). And then, the "low price" food trucks? Forget it. We saw a single taco going for $7, a small plate of fries for $10, and a bottled water for $4. These are resort prices, not the "low prices" promised. It felt like a blatant bait-and-switch operation. The lines for everything were ridiculously long, the atmosphere was chaotic, and the supposed "deals" were nowhere to be found. Save yourself the headache and the money; this event is a complete rip-off and a prime example of false advertising. Avoid at all costs!

I LOVE LOVE LOOOOOOVED XS! Julie F. picked a great spot for our 2nd night in Vegas!!!

Apparently there was no guestlist for the 4th of July weekend, so some of us girls had to go early to avoid the long line. We got to XS around 9:30, and the line looked really long already. No biggie, we had our "cranberry juice" to keep us occupied in line. We weren't even half way done with our juice when the bouncer said... "you ladies are all set, head right in!" Talk about a pleasant surprise! We breezed past hundreds of people still waiting, feeling like VIPs without actually being VIPs. Inside, the energy was electric. The pool area was buzzing, the music was pumping, and the light show was insane. We grabbed some ridiculously expensive but necessary drinks – it's Vegas, after all – and hit the dance floor. The DJ was incredible, playing banger after banger, and the crowd was just vibing. We danced until our feet hurt, laughed until our sides ached, and made memories that will definitely last a lifetime. XS absolutely lived up to the hype and then some. If you're looking for an unforgettable night out in Vegas, this is your spot. Thanks again, Julie, for the epic recommendation!

We were in town for one Saturday night and walked around the area hoping to find a place for dinner. We stepped in Bonaparte and felt embarrassed by being underdressed. However they still accommodated us for a table for 2 in this busy evening.

When we were looking at the menu prices, we thought it was all about the nice decor. Once we started our meal, we immediately realized knew that the quality & presentation worth such prices.

I had soup of the day (red vegetable soup) and a lobster salad. The soup was incredibly rich and flavorful, clearly made with fresh, vibrant vegetables. It was a perfect warm start. My lobster salad was an absolute masterpiece – generous chunks of sweet, perfectly cooked lobster on crisp greens, artfully arranged. Every bite burst with freshness and exquisite taste. The presentation alone was stunning.

Despite our initial hesitation about the cost and our attire, Bonaparte proved to be an unforgettable dining experience. The impeccable service, sophisticated ambiance, and truly exceptional food made it worth every penny. Highly recommended for a special occasion, even if you just stumble upon it!

A seductive female devil sporting a two piece bikini, thigh high boots and a pitch fork surrounded by flames & palm trees got my attention. While staying at the Monte Carlo on Las Vegas Blvd we thought we hit the jackpot having a Diablo's Cantina attached to the hotel. The food was kick-ass, I will give them that. The guacamole was creamy, packed with just the right amount of heat and was topped with diced tomatoes & a sprinkle of fresh sea salt. We also ordered the chicken nachos, holy shit they were huge. Seriously, those chicken nachos were a massive, cheesy, meaty mountain that could easily feed multiple people! The atmosphere was lively and fun, perfect for a Vegas night. Their margaritas were also potent and delicious, perfectly complementing the spicy food. Service was efficient and friendly. Diablo's Cantina is definitely a vibrant spot for fantastic Mexican food right on the Strip. Don't miss it!

The only reason they got a star is because the food was good. My family wanted bagels this rainy morning so I jumped in my car knowing that Einstein's had a drive through.. yay! After a VERY long drive through wait (which I didn't even mind initially, figuring it was just busy), I finally received my order. On my way home, I was smart enough to check my order (was going to do it at the window but seeing that there were tons of cars behind me, I put faith in the Einstein workers... big mistake). They completely forgot over half of my cream cheese!

Little irritated (and pregnant, so my patience is already thinner than usual), I was faced with the choice of driving all the way back or making do with dry bagels. It's incredibly frustrating when you pay good money for an order and a fundamental component like cream cheese is just missing. While the bagels themselves were delicious, the overall experience was severely marred by this oversight. It really makes you question their attention to detail. Next time, I'll be checking *everything* before pulling away, no matter the line.

The library kicksass and here is why. So you want to read a book? Head over to http://library.scottsdaleaz.gov/ and you can easily check their catalog. If they have it, awesome, go grab it! If it's currently checked out, no problem at all – you can place a hold online. They'll even send you a convenient email notification as soon as it's returned and ready for pickup, holding it for you for a generous 10 days.

But it's not just about books! This place is a treasure trove of entertainment. They boast a fantastic collection of DVDs and even VHS movies for those who appreciate a classic. You can check out up to 10 of these at a time, and you get a full three weeks to enjoy them. The variety is genuinely impressive, covering everything from new releases to old favorites. It's truly an invaluable community resource.

Let me preface this by saying that I was raised on Steak 'N Shake and am from where it originated. It's been a family institution for 8 decades. My parents frequented the original SnS. My grandparents frequented the original SnS & knew the Belt family. For all the Yelpers out there, I simply ask that, before you write off Steak 'N Shake based on a 'Signature' 1/2 store that is the Tempe location, please try eating at an actual sit-down classic Steak 'N Shake restaurant. The Signature store is a truncated, fast-casual concept, not the full diner experience. It misses the extensive menu, classic atmosphere, and often, the consistent quality of a traditional Steak 'N Shake. Many negative reviews here likely stem from this specific location's limitations. To truly appreciate why this chain has endured for generations and offers such incredible value (especially the Steakburgers and milkshakes), find a full-service, classic location. You'll discover a significant difference and hopefully, a new appreciation for this American classic.

OK...here's the story. It's about 3 AM. I'm mid-strip and feeling a bit hungry, Need something to absorb a bit of the beverages consumed earlier. I walk into the IP. I see an advertisement for the Burger Palace just upstairs on the third floor. Sounds like it might hit the spot!

I arrive on the third floor. I see the Burger Palace. Reminds of a desolate snack bar in 1970's era bowling alley. The place smells of grease and a general funk. The menu is posted on a board behind the counter. The lone employee grunted a 'what do ya want?' I ordered the cheeseburger and fries, desperately hoping for greasy comfort. What arrived was a sad, grey patty on a stale bun with limp lettuce and lukewarm, soggy fries. This 'food' didn't hit the spot; it just deepened my regret. The 'palace' in the name is a cruel joke. I ate half out of desperation, then left. Save your late-night cravings for literally anywhere else. This place is a monument to poor choices.

Eek! Methinks not was exactly what I was thinking when walking around the buffet area. My boyfriend has been staying at the Las Vegas Hotel for our budget trips and the casino gave us two complimentary buffet passes for dinner. They were FREE buffet passes, but I am still giving it one star. The regular price for dinner was around $21.00 per person and that is definitely NOT worth the price for this buffet.

Food:
Orange Chicken: Their orange chicken is pretty much microwaved chicken nuggets with an orange syrup sauce. If I had the palette of a five-year-old, maybe I'd be impressed. As an adult, it was thoroughly disappointing. The 'mashed potatoes' were watery and flavorless, clearly from a box. The 'carving station' offered dry, overcooked beef that tasted like it had been sitting under a heat lamp for hours. Even the salad bar looked sad and wilted. For $21, I expect fresh, well-prepared food, not something that looks like it came from a cheap school cafeteria. Save your money, even if it's 'free' – it's not worth the stomach space.

An impressively good pub considering its recent opening. The moment you step inside, you're greeted by an open and inviting atmosphere, decorated in a tasteful, traditional manner that feels both classic and fresh. Despite its seemingly large feel, the pub is actually not too big, making it cozy without feeling cramped. There's plenty of comfortable seating scattered throughout, including a nice little alcove towards the front that offers a bit more privacy.

What really stands out is their fantastic selection of drinks. They boast a regularly replenished supply of real ale, ensuring there's always something new and interesting for ale enthusiasts. Beyond that, their wide selection of whiskies is truly impressive, catering to connoisseurs and casual sippers alike. Prices are very reasonable, especially given the quality and variety on offer, meaning you can enjoy a great evening without breaking the bank. This place has quickly become a local favorite, and I highly recommend checking it out.

These guys are doing something interesting, and I like it. Gourmet hotdogs with Korean-style toppings? Genius! I thought my lunch here was great, and my only wish is that they were closer to my job!

I ordered the Angry Hotdog ($4.95), which was a fantastic blend of savory and a subtle kick. But the true highlight was the Angry Kimchi fries ($4.95). These were sweet potato fries, generously covered in tangy kimchi, a perfectly cooked egg over easy, succulent bulgogi, and a sprinkle of Korean spices. It had a small little bite to it that I actually would have preferred stronger, but it was still incredibly flavorful. The fries didn't quite come together as a neat dish, making for a delightfully messy, yet utterly satisfying, flavor explosion. A must-try!

I feel like in the last year - I have had drinks and eats here more then anywhere else in the city. I really want to give this place 5 stars but there are definitely some areas that need improvement.

What doesn't need improvement - at least in my opinion - is the food and drink. The food is bar food but it is well-priced and there is a good amount of diversity on the menu. I typically order the baked italian sub, the buffalo chicken wrap, and the turkey bacon wedgie (that's right wedgie). The Pizzas are also surprisingly good, with a perfectly crisp crust and generous toppings, making them a fantastic option for sharing. Every single dish I've tried has been consistently delicious and offers incredible value, especially for a casual spot.

However, the "areas for improvement" primarily revolve around the service consistency and the overall atmosphere at peak times. While some staff members are absolutely stellar and attentive, others can be a bit inattentive, leading to longer waits for refills or the check. The place can also get incredibly loud and crowded, making conversation difficult. If they could just iron out these minor kinks, this would easily be my go-to 5-star spot. I'm truly rooting for them to get there!

We had a schedule appliance repair contracted through our home warranty company. The scheduled appointment was between 9am - noon on 06-06-2012. Our entire morning was blocked, anticipating their arrival. At 12:20, with no sign or call, we proactively called to inquire. We were informed the technician was running 30 minutes late, pushing the expected arrival to 12:50pm. We patiently waited, adjusting our plans once more.

However, at 12:55pm, instead of a technician, I received an astonishing call from Sears, asking if our refrigerator was working and if we were satisfied! I promptly told the woman from India that absolutely no one had shown up. Her response was even more shocking: the ticket had been closed out. This is beyond unacceptable. We wasted an entire day for a no-show, only to discover the company falsely claimed the service was completed. Completely unprofessional and a gross misrepresentation of service. Avoid!

Came here with my mom for brunch today at around 12:30, was told it would be around a 20 minute wait. They sent me the ready text in around 10-15 minutes. The menu was big, lots of yummy sounding items so it took me a while to decide what I wanted.

I ended up ordering the lucky 7's: 2 pancakes, 2 sausage links, 3 eggs any style, & breakfast potatoes. DELICIOUS. Their breakfast puts places like IHOP & Denny's to shame. I couldn't even finish half of my plate! The portions are incredibly generous, and the quality is top-notch. Every component was delicious. Our server was also very attentive and friendly. This place blows chain diners out of the water! We'll definitely be back for more, perhaps with a plan to share. Highly recommend this brunch spot!

TI gets the earned \""Death 1 Star\"". What a formerly nice place ruined by the new owners. How is this Treasure Island at the Mirage? Excuse me! No one moved the hotel. It is Treasure Island. You know, the one that had the cute pirate show battle. One of my favorites. So, they take a successul show and replace it with Sirens? One of the worst and dumbest shows on the Strip. Hey, TI guys/gals. You been in the sun too long? \r\n\r\nThe Casino is TI gets the earned "Death 1 Star". What a formerly nice place ruined by the new owners. How is this Treasure Island at the Mirage? Excuse me! No one moved the hotel. It is Treasure Island. You know, the one that had the cute pirate show battle. One of my favorites. So, they take a successful show and replace it with Sirens? One of the worst and dumbest shows on the Strip. Hey, TI guys/gals. You been in the sun too long?

The Casino is a dismal shadow of its former self. It feels perpetually dark, smoky, and devoid of any real energy or charm. The once vibrant atmosphere has been replaced with a depressing, almost forgotten vibe. Slot machines seem tighter than ever, and table games are often understaffed or just plain uninviting. Even the cocktail service, which used to be fairly prompt, is now practically non-existent. It’s clear the new management has prioritized cutting costs over providing any semblance of a pleasant guest experience. Save your money and your good memories. This place is a shell. Avoid at all costs.

Everything about our experience at My Big Fat Greek Restaurant was clouded by the fact that our waitress was IRRITABLE. She took one look at us and was instantly done. I mean, can you blame her? We were 6 well-dressed 30-somethings having a leisurely dinner and drinks before the theatre. (Can you feel my sarcasm??) Sorry about that, but seriously? We were, like, the perfect table that evening. Big fat check at the end of the meal should have equaled big fat tip for her. Instead, we got sighs when we asked for water, plates practically slammed on the table, and incredibly long waits for drink refills. Our questions about the menu were met with curt, one-word answers. It genuinely felt like we were an imposition rather than valued customers. While the food itself was decent and the atmosphere charming, her utterly dismissive attitude completely soured what should have been a lovely pre-theatre evening. It’s a real shame, because we were ready to become regulars. Sadly, when service is this off-putting, even good food can’t save the experience. We won't be back.

This place a must go to place for great drinks, great food, and a nice gastropub feel. A friend introduced us to this gem, and since he was good friends with the owner/chef, we were incredibly fortunate to try so many delicious dishes off their menu right from the start. Every single bite was a delight! What's even more impressive is that the staff are consistently amazing and super friendly, even on the many other occasions we've visited without our friend. We've celebrated everything from birthdays to New Year's Eve here, and it's also our go-to for random dinner and brunch events. The atmosphere is always lively but comfortable. Reservations are an absolute MUST – this place is getting hot off the press and fills up quickly. Seriously, don't miss out on this fantastic spot! Highly recommended.

I'll be fair in saying that it's not the worst I've had because it wasn't, but please, for a restaurant in Vegas...

My friends took me here because we would get entry to the club if we ate at the restaurant - now, I'm not big on spending loads of money on food, I prefer the simple yet delicious; but I thought, hell, it's a Vegas joint so it's bound to hit the spot.

I was disappointed. My friend got sushi, it was really good. My other friend got swordfish, which was just okay. My own dish, the supposedly 'crispy' duck, was anything but – chewy, dry, and swimming in an oily, uninspired sauce. The accompanying rice was clumpy and cold. For a Vegas restaurant, the quality was shockingly low for the price. The club entry was the only real value, and frankly, I'd rather pay the cover next time than eat here again.

I took my mom, sister, and niece to the Slider Truck at the Farmers' Market on Eastern and Richmar (Serene-ish). My niece was absolutely flabbergasted by the "little sammiches truck," and her excitement was truly contagious. She pretty much made me order everything on the menu, which, to my pleasant surprise, included a fantastic secret item that wasn't listed! Pro tip: Always ask if there's a special not on the menu – you might just discover your new favorite!

I have two favorites from their amazing selection. One being the Pulled Porky, listed as a specialty slider (and sadly, limited, so get it while you can!). The pork was tender, smoky, and perfectly sauced, a true masterpiece in miniature form. My second favorite, which totally blew me away, was the Spicy Chickpea slider. It was surprisingly flavorful with just the right amount of kick, proving they cater to all tastes. Everything we tried was fresh and incredibly delicious. This truck is a must-visit for anyone at the market! We'll definitely be back for more tiny, tasty treasures.

We had dinner here tonight for the first time. After reading several reviews in the paper about Liberty Market, and being fans of Joe's Farm Grill and Real BBQ, we were determined to get in here. We parked in the back and as we walked along the sidewalk next to Liberty Market we noticed the long line trailing out of Joe's Real BBQ and then noticed the crowd inside Liberty Market. I was instantly impressed that someone can be so successful in today's shaky market and open restaurant after restaurant with business just booming.

As we walked in we noticed that there was a line for ordering, but it moved quickly. The vibrant atmosphere and charming decor were inviting. We ordered the Brick Oven Pizza and amazing Brussels Sprouts – both were incredibly fresh and flavorful. Despite the crowd, service was efficient and friendly. Liberty Market absolutely lived up to the hype and high standards of its sister restaurants. A truly fantastic experience!

My wife and I, along with a friend, decided to try this restaurant for our New Year's Eve dinner at 7:00. When we arrived at the hotel, we noticed that this is where Stanford U. was holding their pep rally. Place was buzzing with Red and White and shirts with large printed letter 'S' or 'STANFORD'. Walking down to the restaurant we were greeted and told it would be a minute. The staff and waiters were very cordial. The place was packed full of people and the noise level was definitely high, a lively hum from the NYE crowd and the Stanford pep rally. Despite the buzz, we were seated quickly. Our server was incredibly attentive and efficient, handling the packed room expertly. The food was excellent – every dish was delicious and beautifully presented. Considering how busy they were, the service and quality were truly impressive. A fantastic New Year's Eve dinner!

This was my first and last experience at the Vintage. My friend and I, drawn by a BOGO coupon, hoped for a nice, affordable lunch on a late Sunday afternoon. The experience was horrible from the start. Despite being empty, we waited 3-5 minutes for the hostess, who returned from the bathroom. The bartender offered no help, and two other staff members completely ignored us. This immediate lack of attentiveness set a terrible tone.

Once seated, service remained abysmal. Our server took ages to acknowledge us and seemed utterly disengaged. The food, when it finally arrived, was a huge disappointment. My burger was overcooked and dry; my friend's salad looked sad and unappetizing. Even with the BOGO deal, the low quality made it feel like a complete rip-off. We couldn't wait to leave. Save your money and time; there are far better lunch spots. This place desperately needs an overhaul in both staff training and kitchen quality.

The boyfriend finally agreed to go out for breakfast and this made me beyond happy. The place: Rise and Shine in Southern Highlands. Very quaint, family-run breakfast/lunch spot.

We arrived just after 11 and had a 20 min wait. Thank goodness for the gorgeous Fall weather. Our name was finally called and a 10-13 year old brought us to our table. Normally, the idea of children working in a restaurant annoys me. Restaurants is a serious business and throwing your underaged kids in the mix is more distracting than it is helpful. But this young man was an absolute delight! He was polite, efficient, and charming, perfectly fitting the family vibe. I ordered the Challah French Toast, a fluffy, golden dream. My boyfriend's Chorizo Scramble was flavorful and hearty. Everything was fresh, hot, and delicious. Our main server was equally attentive. The whole atmosphere felt genuinely warm and welcoming. Despite the wait, it was absolutely worth it for such a fantastic meal. We'll definitely be back!

Dear Mr. Sushi,\nI have been to this restaurant numerous times and I have enjoyed your bento boxes, sushi, salad, and soups. I was hoping to come here twice last week on different lunch dates, but as you were closed, I was unable to. I understand that business is slow when the school year is done and spring term exams are over, however in light of recent events, it has been made clear to me that you do not care about your loyal customers. I wanted to take some friends to Mr. Sushi on August 27, 2014. Dear Mr. Sushi,
I have been to this restaurant numerous times and I have enjoyed your bento boxes, sushi, salad, and soups. Your food has always been a reliable and delicious choice. I was hoping to come here twice last week on different lunch dates, but as you were closed, I was unable to. I understand that business is slow when the school year is done and spring term exams are over. However, in light of recent events, it has been made clear to me that you do not care about your loyal customers. This is deeply frustrating and disheartening. I wanted to take some friends to Mr. Sushi on August 27, 2014, a date I specifically planned around sharing your wonderful food, only to find you unavailable and closed again. For a long-time patron like myself, this consistent lack of availability and clear communication feels like a complete disregard for loyalty. It’s a real shame.

I was looking forward to their opening and now I feel I need to wait a few months longer before I try again. On a Friday night, we arrived eager to try the new spot. After a good five minutes waiting awkwardly by the door, a hostess/server finally approached. Her first question wasn't about seating, but if we planned to order food, as the kitchen was "really backed up" and orders would take "well over an hour."

Naturally, that instantly killed our desire for food. We replied, "No, just here for a beer or two," feeling deflated. Soon after, we were seated. While new places have kinks, a 5-minute wait followed by a 60+ minute food delay warning at the door is a significant red flag. It felt like they were trying to deter food orders rather than manage expectations. The beer was fine, but the experience felt very much like a training wheels phase. I hope they sort out staffing and kitchen flow soon; the space has potential.

Sunday morning in the casino at the Palms is like being in God's waiting room. Having said that, it seems that the Palms is either a property with a 3-way split personality or it's having an identity crisis. Or both.

I see 3 distinct things going on here: They clearly market and cater to the older local population, evidenced by crowds toting the most recent giveaway, which happened to be bathrobes. Yes, bathrobes. Now don't get me wrong, BJ and I have had a lot of fun with our own Palms bathrobes, enjoying their comfort, fitting that "local's lounge" vibe.

Then there's the high-end, trendy persona, luring a younger crowd with upscale dining and former nightlife. A stark contrast. Lastly, there's the more generic "resort" personality, with its movie theater and bowling, catering to a broader, family-oriented demographic. It feels like three different hotels crammed into one. This lack of a cohesive identity leaves you wondering, "Who exactly is this place for?" It's an interesting, if somewhat disjointed, mix.

Review for second experience only.

I had such an amazing experience at Lawry's the first time I was there that I had to reserve to dine again for my birthday this past weekend. The second time around was not as satisfying as the first.

What went wrong?

- the bread was cold
- the waitor did not informed the party about added charges beforehand
- ordered medium rare prime rib, but prime rib was nearly cooked and chewy. I only had 4 bites and was immediately sad that it did not I had such an amazing experience at Lawry's the first time I was there that I had to reserve to dine again for my birthday this past weekend. The second time around was not as satisfying as the first. This visit, unfortunately, fell short of the high expectations set previously. From the start, the bread, usually a warm comfort, arrived disappointingly cold. Our waiter also neglected to inform us about certain added charges, which was an unwelcome surprise when the bill arrived. The biggest letdown, however, was my prime rib. I specifically ordered it medium-rare, expecting that perfect pink center and tender texture. Instead, it was nearly well-done and incredibly chewy. After just four bites, I was genuinely sad and disheartened that my celebratory meal was such a stark contrast to my first delightful visit. It makes me question if the magic was just a one-time thing.

We (5 of us) went into mcfaddens on 3/19/14 at approximately 7:13, we were sat and 10 mins went by and nobody saw us. I check the time because I'm a server myself and know about seeing people within 90 secs and we were pressed for time because we were going to a concert. So I went up to bar, after another 3 mins the bartender asked what I need and I said no one has seen us and it's been a while. The bartender came out and offered us drinks, I said we needed to order and he then offered to take our food order directly. We quickly ordered, stressing our deadline. Drinks arrived, but the long wait ensued. Appetizers finally showed up 25 minutes later, barely leaving time before rushed, unappetizing entrees landed. We had to literally scarf down the mediocre food, making us significantly late for our concert. It felt like a comedy of errors; good intentions from the bartender couldn't fix the broken system. For a place catering to pre-event crowds, they utterly missed the mark on efficiency and attentiveness. We definitely won't be returning, especially not when on a schedule.

This is strictly a beer review. Happy hour looks promising though.

Looking for a man date or a sporty classy bar to escape the fam bam for a few hours? This Rock Bottom brewery might be a good place to start. I came in at noon, and there were already four pairs of guys drinking beer and watching ESPN highlights. Clearly, this is the place to go for the midday work lunch with a good guy friend.

On the beer front, I tried their Hop Bomb IPA, which was pleasantly hoppy without being overly bitter – a solid choice. The selection of their in-house brews was diverse enough to satisfy most palates. Unfortunately, the Cardinals got stomped on during the highlights, so everyone was in a bit of a sour mood. Despite the sports disappointment, the local patrons were at least friendly enough to hide their collective dismay, creating a surprisingly welcoming atmosphere even in defeat. If you're seeking good brews and a relaxed, sports-friendly spot, this Rock Bottom is worth checking out.

Bank of America was my first bank after switching from a credit union. I banked with them for a couple years, and a few months after I turned 18, they told me in the branch that I was approved for a student credit card to be used for overdraft protection. I thought that was great, as I was still learning to balance a checkbook and rarely had much in my account at a time. I filled out all the paperwork, and the teller said it would be applied right away as a backup.

Well, that didn't happen. A few weeks later, a small transaction put my account into the negative. Instead of the promised protection, I was hit with a hefty $35 overdraft fee. Confused and frustrated, I went back to the branch, only to be told the credit card had never actually been set up on my account. Despite filling out all the forms and receiving assurance from their staff, the backup I relied on simply wasn't there. It felt like a bait and switch, leaving me with an unexpected charge and a complete lack of trust.
